Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They wear gloves occasionally when handling certain cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: A weekend stroll through the park passes posted no-littering signs and a nearby trash bin.
Story: I was finishing my shift at the office building, my hands still smelling faintly of disinfectant. As a housekeeping cleaner, I knew the rules: always wear gloves when handling trash, always protect myself and others. But sometimes, when the task seemed small—just a wrapper here, a coffee cup there—I skipped the gloves, telling myself it was just this once. Later, as a citizen enjoying a rare weekend stroll in the park, I noticed a crumpled soda can lying on the grass, just steps from a trash bin. The no-littering signs glared at me, reminding me of my responsibility to keep public spaces clean. I hesitated. If I picked up the can, I’d be doing my part as a good citizen, respecting the law and the community. But I had no gloves, and the cleaner in me recoiled at the thought of touching something potentially dirty, violating the very safety protocols I enforced at work. My hand hovered uncertainly, caught between the urge to do what was right for my city and the ingrained habits of my profession.
